Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Variable Selection for Remedying the Effects of Uncontrolled Variation in Data Driven Predictions
Award.AbstractNarration:
In a project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Steven Brown and Karl Booksh, both from the University of Delaware, and Professor Barry Lavine of Oklahoma State University, seek to improve mathematical and statistical modeling of real-time measurement of chemical species. This research is aimed at reducing the cost-of-ownership of calibration and classification models that have become increasingly common in process monitoring, quality assurance and quality-by-design applications by studying the ways in which these models fail and by searching for ways to stabilize the modeling. The broader impacts of this project include the improvements in efficiency and performance from improved and more reliable chemical models for production and quality assurance, as well as the training of graduate and undergraduate students in data analysis, a skill in very high demand.

This project is a collaborative effort aimed at investigating fundamental issues important to chemical modeling in modern measurement science: (1) stabilizing calibration and classification relationships in the presence of unexpected contributions, (2) making calibrations and classifications as robust as possible to additional sources of background, and (3) improving classification and calibration models measured over multiple instruments. Methods for automated identification of the portions of the chemical responses that best model the system are being investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many chemical analyses are performed by measuring the change in intensity of light passing though or reflecting from a sample. Getting the identity and the amount of the components in the sample is a challenge, especially for samples where the amounts are small and the light intensity changes are similar for several components. When an unknown component is present, estimating amounts of the known components becomes more difficult because of the overlap in the light changes produced by the unknown with the changes produced by the known components. For the past thirty years, measuring the variation in light intensity as a function of the amounts of known components has been used to calibrate for the known components using a data-driven model, but this approach fails when any kind of unexpected variation is present, either from unknown components or from other changes in the way the mixture responds to light, even from use of a different device to make the measurement.

This project has focused on discovering new methods to correct for unanticipated sources of variation in a chemical measurement. One way of dealing with the problem is to find what light wavelengths are least affected by an unknown, then use only these in a calibration.This approach was explored and several novel methods were reported. One in particular permits a calibration to be used even when there are sources of variation not expected from the original components, a situation that occurs when measurements for a calibration are done on one instrument and the calibration is used on a second instrument, something that is common in chemical analysis of samples  for quality assurance or biomedical monitoring. Getting the calibration relationship to work on the second instrument is problematic, and this problem has limited use of variation-based calibration in routine analyses. Our work on this project has resulted in a new way to permit the calibration to be used on instruments not used to measure the original samples, opening the possibility for increased use of variation-based calibrations. More importantly, we chose not to patent this work, and our method is available to all.

A second challenge in chemical processes monitored by the way light is changed involves the need to adapt a mathematical model for the calibration to changes in the process dynamics caused by changes to the feedstock or to changes that occur in the sensors used to monitor the process. Any calibration model based on these "soft-sensors" must be able to account for these changes in real-time, as the chemical production process proceeds. Work on this project considered several ways of adapting process calibrations to changing process conditions. We reported several novel methods, including one where the important sensors are discovered and used, and where sensors that are less important to the calibration are adaptively ignored. We also found a new way to use time-based changes to monitor the process and to predict new samples. This new method has applications in the chemical industry as well as in the field of quantitative finance. And, we demonstrated the use of new methods from the field of artificial intelligence for monitoring and adapting calibrations relevant to chemical processes.

Much of the background related to these studies was summarized in five new critical reviews.

Some data-driven predictions involve identifying what is present rather than calibrating how much of a given known is present. This project also considered new methodology for spatial identification. The focus was on chemical and spatial identification of components and identification of sample origin.

In one study, geological mixtures from meteorite impacts were examined by monitoring light scattered from the sample upon laser excitation, and the spatial distribution of several titanium oxide minerals and quartz was studied. New methods for separating the overlapped signals from these samples were discovered and reported. A similar approach was used to examine historical cultural artifacts. The spatial distribution of pigments was identified, with a goal of demonstrating changes in the historical use of green copper pigments in paints. A third investigation examined the identification of the brand of edible oils from spectra.

In a second study, protected tropical wood samples from 12 countries were examined by using amounts of trace impurities in the samples. The geospatial distribution of the trees producing the wood samples and the biological phylogeny of the wood samples were related to the trace metal signatures, permitting a new wood sample to be identified as to both its country of origin and its species of wood, a new form of provenance analysis that will prove useful to forensic work  and to regulatory agencies charged with protecting endangered species. These new data analysis methods will also have wider application in other places where the origin and history of a sample is important.
